title: Arduino Uno and Half Size Breadboard Holder

description.text:
A basic and simple Arduino Uno and half size breadboard holder. I prefer to have the Arduino above my breadboard but many designs have it below so I threw together my own. Very simple, 10% infill and prints in about an hour. The spacers I used were made for the LCD display for my Makerfarm printer. The spacers were not created by me but can be found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335589
I used M2 hardware to toss it together and 4 PVC feet on the bottom corners. I have included the FreeCAD files so that the design can be altered if necessary.

title: Mini FPV V-Quadcopter by jsobanski (Inspired by Emaglio)

description.text:
THIS IS STILL A WORK IN PROGRESS Hi everyone. Emaglio (Creator of the Mini FPV Tricopter) is a good friend of mine and suggested I create a V-Quadcopter for the community. I've been busy with work and school but I'd like to test the waters with the design here on thingiverse! Like I mentioned before this is still a work in progress, and has yet to actually fly.I am hoping to get some good feedback to tweak the design so everyone is happy, and maybe see a few get airborn ;). I should note, the STL's that I have uploaded are with the changes I needed to make to accommodate my printer. This included widening the rear arm slots by .3mm. If lots of people run into problems I can upload a new STL. Hopefully they yield successful results for you! General parts list
  • SunnySky 2204 2300kV motors
  • Gemfan 5x3 Props
  • Magic 12A ESCs with SimonK
  • 3S 1200mah -1300mah Battery (depending on size)
  • Naze32 Flight Controller
  • PZ0420M FPV Camera
  • 3mm hardware
    • Please leave comments and suggestions!

Everything should be a snap fit and stay nice and snug with an assortment of 3mm hex bolts. You'll need 10mm, 15mm, and 35mm with a nut. Bottom Solid Layers: 3
Top Solid Layers: 3
Layer height: 0.2mm
Number of Perimeters: 2

author: dberube

title: alpha parts of three speed bicycle hub

description.text:
This is an attempt to create an internally geared bicycle hub, based on the Sturmey Archer A-3 design from 1914. Because the schematics are so old, I am 99.9% sure that copyright has expired and that they are now public domain. It is very alpha quality. I have no way to test making it so I don't know if the files work. I also haven't drawn all the parts; I've run out of time so here is an upload of what I have so far. Theoretically the gears should at least mesh and spin, if you put the axle, the planetary gears and the ring gears together. Why create it then? To test certain questions:
  • Can you make complicated stuff in openscad?
  • Are there interesting old designs that are not only patent-expired, but copyright expired? (early 20th century stuff)?
  • Can plastic prototype hubs help the understanding & design of a real metal hub?
  • Can public domain parts files help with re-use?
    • This project uses a modified form of the following public domain project: Parametric Involute Spur Gear by Leemon Baird, 2011,
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5505 Old Sturmey Archer hub design schematics can be found here:
    http://www.sturmey-archerheritage.com/index.php?page=history&type=technic&era=1 Cornell University has a great guide to Copyright and the Public Domain, discussing the expiration dates for copyright. It is here:
    http://copyright.cornell.edu/resources/publicdomain.cfm

I have no access to a 3d printer, so I don't know how to make it. 
However if you did print out this alpha partially-completed set of parts,  you should be able to at least put the axle in the middle of the planetaries, and have them fit into the ring gear, and get it to spin. 
Fully assembling an internal bicycle hub is like assembling a puzzle. You can buy actual old metal hubs off of ebay, and view service manuals on the internet, in order to gain understanding and practice.

title: Direct filament drive for Cyclops extruder

description.text:
The cyclops extruder hot-end from E3D is a fantastic idea. The concept of a single nozzle with multiple colors solves a lot of problems.
The extruder hot end is designed for bowden style extruders which i do not think are as reliable as direct drive. I designed components to allow the hotend to now be direct drive

Printer:

Home Built 600mm x 300mm x 300mm

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

print the body (extruder chasis block)
print LH lever (fix for extruder lever 2 LH
print RH lever (fix for extruder lever 2
For the lever pivot i used a 5mm rod drilled and tapped each end for 3 mm screws.
Remove 1 assembly screw from each of the stepper motors. This is going to be where the lever pivot will be attached
Drill out the threaded hole on the shaft side of the body
I used MK7 Filament drive wheel which you can buy online
Cut the shaft of the steppers so that they do not protrude past the filament drive wheel
You will need 2 long 3mm screws...the ones i used i got from an old extruder.
assemble the cyclops hot end as per instructions
Mount the cyclops onto the bottom of the extruder chasis block with 3 screws that have been supplied with the cyclops
using 4mm ptf tubing push the tubbing into the 4mm holes down to the base of the cyclops extruder heat block....you will not be able to push it any further
Using correct length of 3mm socket head screws assemble the stepper motors to the Extruder chasis block
Assemble the levers and bearings (I used 4mm set scres of the correct legth
push lever pivot through both levers
find two strong enough springs for tension (its obvious where the springs go)
you will have to hold the springs and push levers and lever pivot into position then start one of the long 3mm screws
then i used a clamp to push the other side of the levers into position so that i could start the opposite screw
tighten all screws
then test
make sure that the extruder is not going over speed....i had spent a lot of time correcting this
the max input filament should be no more that 10mm sec (this is actually a normal speed for most extruders)
Have fun

description.text:
The Kossack is a redesign of Blomker's Kossel-mini NEMA17 extruder using a 608 bearing instead of a 625, combined with biomushroom's NEMA17 40:9 planetary gearbox.  
By their powers combined, I have a working Bowden-compatible extruder using a MK7 gear despite my rather lackadaisical stepper motor.

Requires:
1 x 608 bearing
1 x 625 bearing
6 x M3 25mm cap-screw
7 x M3 15mm cap-screw
7 x M3 nut
1 x M5 hex-head screw
3 x 1gear.stl, 1 x every other STL This is assembled more or less the same way as the "Raldrich planetary nema17". The Kossack completely replaces its top plate. Also see the exploded view. As usual, the SCAD is on bld3r: http://www.bld3r.com/obj/5842251410309120

title: Printrbot Handle Spool for 1.25" spool holes

description.text:
The spool holder included with the Printrbot Simple is too big for my Hatchbox spool! Also, a filament guide is handy, as is a stop to keep the spool clear of the Y arm. So I made this. Each file prints in about 1:40.
  • Rotate the plate 45 degrees and it should fit on your build plate. It will have to be printed separately from the arm pieces.
  • Fill 40% or greater, no brim or raft needed. Use support on the plate.
  • Insert the flat piece into the slot on the arm, and slide the arm assembly onto the plate. Some PLA cement is nice but not really necessary.
    • UPDATE: The filament guide was too small, and wanted to be angled. The FIXED-GUIDE file replaces the old one with a larger filament guide hole on an angle.

comments.text: Hey man. This is great. I made one mod to it, but with a drill, as I am new to 3d modeling. I found that my spools would travel to the far end of the spool holder (gravity) over time; which would cause the filament to pop off the side of the spool. So, I drilled some hole along the shaft and added a thin bar into the hole to keep it from sliding down. I was thinking about modifying your design a bit to put in notches to put in half a cd (broken in half) to better hold the spool in place.

description.text: Just another hummingbird feeder

Support is needed when printing the flowers and the top part, this will work with any standard mouth soda/water bottle. No need to glue or screw anything together, the flowers press fit into the holes. Remove the retainer ring left on the plastic bottle from the cap, then press the top cover onto the bottle to replace the plastic ring. Fill your bottle with some un-colored sugar water, and screw the dish bottom onto the bottle top and flip over and set anywhere the birds can get to it.

comments.text:
I am currently printing this (with remixed bottle feeder dish to fit the print bed area of my M3D- will post when complete)
It took a little time to clean up the top, yes it does require support. I have rotated the flower bits to use support and raft, just so the tops of the flowers are finished cleanly. The feeder dish and top are pink, the flowers are bright yellow, I am printing the first flower now rotated -180 degrees x axis so the top of the flower is cleanly finished, face down was a disastrous print most likely because I did not use supports.
But it has been my experience that a cleaner finish is offered on the top of the print and often times I will rotate the print so it finishes public display side facing up.
Also, I printed the feeder dish without supports, High quality and it turned out well. I did not use CURA.

title: RC Car
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I'm designing a 1:25th scale rc car. One of my main goals is to make this car printable on the smallest of printers, so all parts will be well within 100mm square build volume. Other goals include: Uses common hardware of a single type for the whole design, (currently Metric M3 bolts and nuts), and overall ease of use, build quality, function. It is a work in progress so bare with me... UPDATE 7-3-2017 : I revisited this project again after 2 years.... Sorry people of the internet! Made some more changes (We can finally turn!) there are some new parts and I am working on the drive system. not sure yet if I want to go with a belt drive or shaft drive. Maybe I have a new type of drive system in mind.... UPDATE 7-25-2015 : Made changes to the whole model. The A-arms have been updated so there are no overhangs and they lay flat for printing, Shock towers complete redesign, chassis pan is lighter now, and added new part "Bearing carrier".
I am working on making the turning knuckles and the top control-arms. I would like to having a rolling chassis in a few months, let me know if you want to help. :)
  • "A" arms
  • Chassis pan
  • Shock Towers
  • Bearing Carriers

• Print the printables
  • Assemble with Metric M3 hardware
  • Enjoy!

title: Sturdier RepRap Prusa i3 Aluminium corner pieces

description.text:
Beast up your RepRap Prusa i3 with aluminium corner pieces.
No threaded rod protruding from the front!

  • Cut or machine 20x20mm stock, drill respective holes and tap here and there... use grub screws instead of zip ties to hold the smooth rods. So shiny and sturdy!

    • see more at:
    droopas.blogspot.com

I recommend the SketchUp (.skp) file to get an idea of placement of holes.
  • Machine four pieces of 20x20mm stock to a length of 52mm.
  • In all pieces, drill through two 8 mm holes 10mm and 30mm from the bottom. These holes will accept the 8mm threaded rods.
    Also drill a 8mm hole perpendicular to the previous holes 45mm from the bottom. This hole should be 15 mm deep to hold the smooth rods. Drill and tap a hole to accept grub scew to hold the smooth rod. I found M6 works nicely.
  • In the two front corner pieces, drill 8.5mm holes 15mm into the block and tap with M10 parallel to the smooth rods. These holes are drilled 20 mm from the bottom
  • In the two back corner pieces drill 10mm holes parallel to the smooth rod holes.
    • Assemble by two M10 threaded rods and use nuts to fasten, and four M8 threaded rods and nuts (use dome nuts if you want it to look fancy).

comments.text: Perfect! I am building a Prusa i3 style printer with a 200 x 300 mm bed and using 10mm rods for the Y-axis. This will work perfect!

title: Filament Coil Holder for Lulzbot Mini (remix)

description.text: The stock filament holder for the Lulzbot Mini is basically a printed stick and it works fine most of the time, but I did have the filament in a couple long overnight print jobs get jammed because the printer had to tug hard on the filament to overcome the friction between the spool and the stock coil holder. So I decided to replace it with something a little better. I used the spool centers and knob without modification from this project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:219667 The skate bearings had a nice snug "tap 'em in" sort of fit. I had to use epoxy on a 5/16" nut for the knob. I printed the knob pointy side down with a brim -- the wide end is a thing of beauty. I was skeptical it would print OK, but it came out awesome. Then I made a bracket to replace the stock holder -- my bracket holds a 5/16" carriage bolt (round head with a square section underneath (2d photo)) and then those spool centers slide on and the knob with captured nut screws it all down. The bracket I made is a little overwrought, but I was using it to work on my (weak) FreeCad skills. Despite that, it works great -- my overnight print jobs no longer suffer from the filament jamming itself tight into the spool. If anything, it spins a bit too free now and when printing fast, it can sort of unspool a bit extra. I used an 8" carriage bolt but clearly, a 7.5" would have been ample. The bolt's hole in the bracket will need to be bored most likely, mine did - use a 5/16" bit of course. The square hole on the backside should be snug enough to hold the bolt in place (tap it in while the piece is still warm or use the captured nut to pull it tight -- if loose, there is always epoxy) but you could also put a nut out in front if you want -- it isn't really necessary unless the carriage bolt is loose and wants to fall out. When the nut knob is tightened down, it holds the whole pancake together. The spool centers have skate bearings in them. I had some laying around so I used those, but I think you could just fill the central holes and then make a 5/16" +smidge hole through them and go without the bearings. You'd also want to get some nylon washers in this case, or print up some washers. That might be the perfect balance that prevents unwanted unspooling at speed and also prevents excess drag. The source files are included -- it's FreeCAD's native file format. I've also included just the basic hole pattern for the stock spool arm if you want to make your own filament support entirely. The screws fit snugly, might need to be worked through with a hex but they line up with the screw holes on the Lulzbot part perfectly. The holes aren't perfectly centered in the block -- one side meets the top of the Lulzbot part without sticking up or down -- what I mean is that the top of the bracket is even with the top of the Lulzbot part. I could have made the block wider and centered the stuff -- don't know why I didn't. You can though if you like.

description.text:
Simple latching bike mount enclosure for your Sony Smartwatch3 Core.
For handlebars (20-22 mm).
Ties to Bars with cable ties.
PETG version allows easier USB charger access (for those long rides) and includes "SONY" branding on cover...

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: Prints best in PETG. I use 2 or three perimeters.

Assembly and clean-up Install button from inside with a pair of pliers. Notice that the button base is asymmetric to reach the watch button and install accordingly. This can be quite tricky so you many want to print a couple of spare buttons.
Supports break off easily requiring a little clean-up.

Designed to print in PLA and PETG without supports with 15% infill and 2 shells.
Use a panel pin or a cut paper-clip for the hinge pin.
Support added to model so you don't have to worry about it.
Print a few extra buttons at 80% infill if you're using PLA. I broke a couple getting them fitted. PETG is super tough so no worries there. NEW: The PETG Model includes an opening for USB charging on the go for those looooong rides. Model also adapted for low PETG shrinkage rates and the hinges are reversed to previous to be more logical.

comments.text: Interesting. This is almost a "Soma cube," which is a classic 3x3 cube dissection puzzle. Is it really possible to assemble a 3x3 cube when both of these are the same piece?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Believe it or not, it is still possible to solve it with two of the same "chiral" pieces! I was originally planning on re-creating a Soma Cube puzzle by making them mirror images of each other, but had some weird software problems, and decided to stick with what I had...two of the same piece! I was really surprised to find that it's still solvable :)

description.text: This is the base file I am using to create add-ons for the new portable version of CRASH space's Store Front Music we did last year.  It is a 12x12 grid of quarter inch holes labeled Cartesian style with 0 in the middle.  It is going to save me a "hole" bunch of time (sorry), hopefully it will save someone else time, too.

OPTION 1: Download file, use it to do layouts of items that need to have peg board spaced holes. Delete holes you don't need when done with your layout. Cut or drill as your project/tools you've got calls for.
OPTION 2: Download file, open it, copy the holes to make the dimensions of the pegboard you need (up to 11 x 23 is you are epilog laser cutting ). Laser cut your new pegboard. Or print out, tape, drill, if you are more patient than me!

title: Darth Vader Key Fob... Your keys to the Dark Side!

description.text:
Star Wars fans will appreciate this simple print. May your keys be with you!  
Slim / flat print for use as a key fob with Darth Vader's unique features... obviously best printed in black. Approx. 50mm wide / tall at standard scale. Suggest printing at high resolution (0.1mm) for the best detail and finish.   
And... if you like this print check out my other designs!

Suggest printing at high resolution (0.1mm) in black with raft. Use 3 shells (or more) and 50% infill.  
Can be scaled up/down slightly. Standard scale is approx. 49.5mm (W) x 47mm (H) excluding key ring attachment x 6.75mm (D)

I found an example of this in Publix and decided to make my own version. The product I started with is made from soft rubber, but I think hard plastic will work OK. Features not in an ordinary funnel model include: internal fins to secure an upright bottle as a source, grips on the side to help remove the source bottle, an air escape channel for the sink bottle, and grips on the spout to maintain stability of the sink bottle. Imaging how much shampoo or hand soap you could save with this efficient transfer device! Also, with a little modification, this might make an easy device for demonstrating a vortex with two 2-liter bottles.
I haven't tried to print this yet. The depth of the side grips may present a problem.

title: Bullbar and Winch bumper fits a 3Racing Winch

description.text: Custom Winch bumper made for my custom chassis. Comes in 3 parts, the main winch bumper that has been designed for a 3Racing winch, the winch brackets which I used to make it easier to fit the winch to bumper but are not necessary and the bull bar which can also be attached. You will need to design a bracket to make it suit your vehicle. Printed at 33% the only to break is the little hoops on the front right, which should be visible in the photos. The Ground Anchor/Pull Pal is NOT my work and can be found http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:739294 created by sirmakesalot.

remixed_from.author: jamesarm97
remixed_from.title: Z Axis Anti wobble for Prusa I3

title: Z Axis Anti Backlash for Prusa I3 for M8 or 5/16" threaded rods

description.text:
Z axis anti-backlash for Prusa I3 for using M8 or 5/16" threaded rods.
I modified the design of thing:141479 to allow the X axis to be stable even if a CNC attachment is added to the X carriage. My preference is to print 2 of each (LHS & RHS) parts for top and bottom of the X-carriage. You might choose to only use one of the LHS or RHS instead. If using parts for top and bottom, you can just use one nut in the bottom section. The top section takes care of backlash while the bottom section takes care of stability. I will shorten the part to fit just one nut for the bottom portion. just takes 1 simple value change in SCAD file attachment if you are up to it. I have provided more clearance for pushing nuts inside the nut trap, so after pushing the nuts in, just push some paper or plastic tabs next to the nut to stop it from moving. M3 holes will have to be drilled into the X carriage to attach this part to it. Since the X axis will be sandwiched between the LHS & RHS parts, the M3 bolts are only required to keep the X-carriage from slipping.
I drilled out the M5 nut hole in the X-carriage to accommodate my 5/16" threaded rod. I uploaded the SCAD file in case you want to modify any feature of this thing. You could use this as a quick reference on how to modify any existing STL file. UPDATE:
Added short LHS and RHS versions for single nut.

comments.text: can you please post a picture of how it looks on it ?
comments.author: InventingJ

comments.text: I never imagined that I would use a 3d pen to enclose the free hanging nut, and print the form fixing enclosure for it. I am now a believer in 3d pens to crude fix machined 3d prints to fit them to our use.

I have designed these corner posts to mount ATX PSU's under a table or bench using nylon ties. But they can actually be used to suspend any parallelepiped-shaped volume (within reason, obviously).  
OpenSCAD source is included so the thing can be further remixed.  
License is GPLV3.

Print two pairs of corner mounts. I printed these in PLA with 40% infill.  
Requires 8 x wood screws (2 per corner mount) and 2 x wide, long nylon ties + 2 x thin nylon ties.  
Mark and pre-drill the holes for the wood screws, screw the mounts to the table/bench, then install the PSU over the mounts and attach with the wide nylon ties properly tightened. The thin nylon ties are just a precaution against the wider ones accidentally slipping out of place.

comments.text:
After nearly a year, i finally printed these and mounted my psu under the desk.
Thank you for the design! Works great!

This is an Open-Hardware project to develop a simple LIDAR 3D-Scanner. First Test: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kiH7LBjazDM The project is still under development. The first part was to develop the hardware. Next, we are going to hack the Laser range finder with a LR4 board from Porcupine electronics and write the code. If you are interested, follow the project at: http://www.diy3dscan.com/viewforum.php?f=45

comments.text: So what's the idea here? A laser range finder is moved across the thing to be scanned?
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: Porcupine Electronics built an USB interface to this scanner (which has not yet arrived). The range finder sends the distance via usb to the computer. I know the position of the stepper motors and the distance from the range finder, therefore, I should be able to calculate a pointcloud of a room for example. The range finder has a working distance of about 50 meters. I hope that this 3D-scanner (LIDAR) can be used for scanning very big structures (in low resolution). Please watch the hardware demo, it should make the idea more clear.

title: Rotary Hydroponic Unit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Who said we couldn't print useful things? Here's a flat-pack modular rotary hydroponic unit to be produced by most CNC tools. My Blog Post about this here: http://engineeringourfreedom.blogspot.com/2011/05/do-cartwheels-feed-people.html For working examples of such a system, see OmegaGarden.com RotoGro.com or H2ODynamic.com Call it the ModRotoHydro, RapFarm, FeederBot, [email protected], or whatever else you like, I don't care, just help me build them and feed the world. ;D Some bits of the assembly are made from or based on standard mendel parts, such as the frame vertex and Prusa's Y-bar clamps. The current gear-tooth profile is based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8077; I might try a version with an easier-to-print zigzag, though it may be less efficient. The cylinder has an outer diameter of 1 metre, ID of 80cm, and the trays are designed to hold 75mm/3" rockwool cubes, though it would be very easy to design alternate holders for smaller sizes. Currently I have designed the system to use a gear ratio of 11/1056, i.e. 44 teeth on each of 24 segments, using a 3-3.6rpm synchronous motor pulled from the base of a broken halogen heater. If you want me to release alternative parts, e.g. with different numbers of teeth on the segment, just say so and I'll get on it for you. I have been designing the base-frame to try and use 1m lengths of studding with as little random waste as possible, but you could construct this at different sizes with odds and ends if you so wish. It doesn't make a difference so long as a tray and reservoir can fit under the cylinder. The tray support designed is now up. It uses 8mm studding to span the gap in the design, but I think you could possibly use some 6mm dowel, but don't take my word for it until you or I have done a stress calculation. I'm thinking of having it so you simply hang a polyethylene sheet across the gap in the base to make a sump for the nutrients. There needs to be a hole in the bottom to drain excess away into a reservoir though, and some kind of hose line up from the reservoir to pump it in. The weight-saving gaps have mostly been placed conservatively using intuition and best practice of avoiding sharp corners, but I have yet to do any FEA on the components to see if this can be improved for even more strength and less weight. However, I expect design 1.0 to work as it is with lightweight infill settings. Any DXF files that end with a measurement are giving the reccomended thickness of sheet to cut the part out of, in order to fit within this design, however you may be able to change these around a bit and file holes down to fit. Let me know if you want another file format. I added a DXF of the geared segment face on request, for anyone able to cut that profile halfway through a 10mm board. I promise I'll get round to drawing up a less-botched-together motor mounting part that follows some kind of one-size-fits-all geometric rule (eventually).

Use the supplied eDrawings executable assembly file to take relevant measurements.

  • Acquire studding, nuts, bolts, washers, bearings, plastic or mdf, lights, a low-speed motor, some grow medium and hydroponic fertiliser. (Optional: water pump and timer) (Alternative - build the base out of MDF or any scrap wood/fibreboard pulled from a skip, with a few holes to mount rollers/bearings on)

  • Print or laser-cut all the flat structural parts.

  • Cut and file studding to size.

  • Build a base appropriate to the number of rings you want in a cylinder.

  • Fit your lights, motor and feeding tray.

  • Build as many rings as you can fit on the base.

  • Test that the motor turns the cylinder through one full rotation in about 30-40 minutes.

  • Soak rockwool cubes and balance the pH of the surrounding solution to about 6.

  • Germinate seeds or propagate cuttings in 1-inch rockwool cubes.

  • Plug the starter cubes with well-rooted seedlings into holes in the 3" cubes.

  • Quickly load the cubes into the trays on an assembled ring, and secure them with the grow-medium retainer pins.

  • Rest your planted ring on the base (Optional: adjust the base width if you already have one or more on there, and bolt them together)

  • Hit the lights and start the motor.

  • Set your timer to pump nutrient solution into the sump for 1 hour a day, every day, or DIY with a jug.

  • Eat tasty fresh food! ^_^ (Especially things out of season that would be wasteful to import)
    • *...Oh wait, there's a step in there somewhere about replacing old media, but who cares... :P

description.text: this is a remix of "Back to the future" gadget - printable 4 color Flux Capacitor, by Immaginaecrea. I made it larger and merged it into a few single color pieces. the insides can be printed clear and painted. im going to make the case in silver. I paused the print a few times and changed colors i started the inside in clear then changed to black for the top shells, then back to clear for the capacitor layers. the case started as black even though i wanted the front grey. i only had a few feet of grey left so i just used it for the top shells then back to black for the labels. I removed the wires and made holes for real wires. This has holes in back for large LEDs, im writing arduino software to make it flash in sequence.

https://youtu.be/AC4DlJVLb5k arduino code for the flashing LEDs
hook the positive of all the leds to 3,or 5 volt output
hook the negative of each ring (outer, center, and inner) to. pin 8,9,10
///////////////////////////next line and on//////////////////// int delayTime = 70;// time between blinks, change the number higher //for slower, lower for faster. 1000=1second void setup()
{
pinMode(8, OUTPUT); //outer leds
pinMode(9, OUTPUT); //second outer leds
pinMode(10, OUTPUT); //center led
//pinMode(11, OUTPUT); }
void loop() //this means Perform functions again and again
{ digitalWrite(8, LOW); delay(delayTime);
digitalWrite(8, HIGH);
digitalWrite(9, LOW); delay(delayTime);
digitalWrite(9, HIGH);
digitalWrite(10, LOW); delay(delayTime);
digitalWrite(10, HIGH); }

title: 3Drag Hotend: CAD of the PTFE parts

description.text:
CAD files (.iges and .stl) of the 3Drag Hotend.  
Parti CAD (.iges and .stl) dell'hotend della 3Drag.

Starting from a PTFE rod of 20mm diameter you can make these two parts using a lathe. Note that cilindro_PTFE has a thread of M8 (metric iso thread) on the narrow end.  
Utilizzando una barra tonda di 20 mm è possibile costruirsi queste due parti utilizzando un tornio. Da notare che l'estremità stretta del cilindro in PTFE termina con una filettatura M8.
